responses: Currently, the rate of data transfers over 4g is 20 megabits per second, while on 5g you can transfer data at up to 1 gigabit per second.  I’m reading that the difference is “20 to 100 times faster”, but it depends on the kind of data transfer you’re doing, so just for an order-of-magnitude sense of things, let’s say that in general 5g is around 20 times faster than 4g.

responses:
“Know” is a strong word.  
It’s difficult to precisely determine if your baby is getting the milk she needs for her ideal health.  A lot of the first few weeks of your baby’s life depend on a “rhythm” of feeding and sleeping.  The first six weeks are especially delicate, with brain development occurring at a rapid pace.  If you’re nursing, then you need to keep an eye on your baby’s feeding pattern to make sure she’s getting enough milk for her to grow well.

Your baby will probably have hungry periods and sleepy periods.  The most important thing to do is to try to feed her when she’s hungry, and to let her sleep when she wants to.

It’s also very important to try to make feeding schedules.  Many new mothers notice that their babies seem to have a lot of hungry periods when they’re going through the first six weeks, and this is absolutely normal and normal for their bodies to have that hunger.  Babies grow very quickly during this time, and it’s important that they get enough milk.  
I know it can be frustrating if you have trouble getting your baby to eat as much as she should, so try
Can you be a little more specific?  Are you wondering how much milk is appropriate, or whether she is getting a good milk supply?

responses:
If you want to prevent a cold from occurring, the most important step is to make sure you’re getting plenty of rest and exercise. Also, be sure to practice good hygiene by washing your hands frequently and making sure you’re always breathing fresh air. Finally, make sure you’re eating a balanced diet.

If you already have a cold, there are a few things you can do to help alleviate it. Drink plenty of water, and hot tea with lemon and honey. Drink ginger or turmeric supplements (to be safe, consult your physician first). Practice relaxation exercises like meditation, yoga, tai chi, or progressive muscle relaxation. Do some light exercise like walking or stretching.

You might also want to take a steam or hot shower, or put a warm or cold compress on your face. Make sure you’re sleeping well, and if you’re having any trouble sleeping, you might want to try some natural sleep aids like melatonin, or some teas like chamomile or passionflower.

The best way to prevent a cold is to exercise frequently and eat a healthy diet.  Both can help you stay well-rested and strong, and also can help you stay well-hydrated.  If you already have a cold, you might want to try some over-the-counter cold remedies to help you feel better, or some natural cold remedies such as ginger, honey, or cinnamon.  You might also want to make sure you’re getting enough sleep.

If you already have a cold, there are a few things you can do to help alleviate it. Drink plenty of water, and hot tea with lemon and honey. responses: Well, you might think that the agency would randomly select a set of taxpayers, but actually it’s not quite that simple.  There is a process called “information returns selection,” which takes the total number of information returns filed by an I.R.S. District and assigns those returns to different categories of examinations, based on a number of factors.  These factors include a variety of statistics about the returns and the taxpayers themselves, and they’re also used to assign a particular risk level to each of the categories of examinations.  The information returns selection process is sometimes called “return selection,” which is a little bit confusing.  Once a set of returns have been assigned to a particular category of examinations, the agency uses this category of returns to select a set of taxpayers to audit.  For example, let’s say we have a category of returns called “Corporate.”  In this category, about 25% of returns selected are audited, and about 75% of the remainder are managed with a variety of correspondence procedures.

If you haven’t been audited, then you’ve been very lucky!  In recent years, audits have become more common, especially among high-income individuals, who are generally more likely to have complicated returns or report significant income from investments.  If you’re not sure whether or not you’ve been audited, you can look at the agency’s audit search site.  When you search the site, you should look for yourself by name (not by your Social Security number, if you have one) and set the “Return Type” option to “Publication”.  If you don’t see any results, then you can be pretty sure that you haven’t been audited.  If you do see results, but none of the information in the list is relevant, then you’re in luck: in that case, you’re definitely not an audit target.

responses: In terms of cancer treatment, a second opinion can be a good way to understand what the most likely options are, and help to understand any treatment plans that might be available to you. It’s worth noting that a second opinion isn’t always possible, and when it’s not possible it can be helpful to look for other information on the internet. For example, a friend might know another expert in the area, or a hospital might have an online database of doctors in your area. Or it might be worth trying to book an appointment with an expert in the field, but you might need to be patient in doing this.
